preview_html:
The Premier League’s race for European spots heats up as Manchester United welcome Fulham to Old Trafford on February 1, 2026. Both sides have shown resilience this season, with United vying for a top-four finish and Fulham pushing for the upper half of the table. Recent trends suggest a closely fought contest is on the cards.

The last meeting between these two teams ended in a 1-1 draw at Craven Cottage in August 2025. Fulham edged possession with 52% and recorded more shots (13 to United’s 10), creating 62 dangerous attacks. Manchester United, although slightly behind in the attacking metrics, managed to level the score through Emile Smith Rowe’s 73rd-minute strike after an own goal from Rodrigo Muniz had given Fulham the lead earlier in the second half. The match underscored both teams’ ability to create chances and maintain composure under pressure.

When examining Manchester United’s recent performances, their consistency at home stands out. Across their last 11 home matches, they have avoided defeat in nine, and they have achieved a 50% win rate over the last 40 home games in all competitions. United also maintain steady attacking output at home, averaging 5.9 shots on target and near 54% ball possession in this spell. In Premier League play, their home record reads seven wins from the last 14 home fixtures, and they have gone undefeated in 10 of their last 12 league games at Old Trafford.

Fulham, meanwhile, have been difficult to beat in recent outings. They have gone undefeated in eight of their last 10 matches in all competitions and boast a strong league run with 88% of their past eight games ending without a loss. On the road, Fulham managed to win half of their last six away encounters but also lost 58% of their most recent 12 away fixtures, indicating some inconsistency when playing outside London.

Season-long performances reinforce why both clubs are within striking distance of their objectives. United sit fourth on 38 points after 23 matches, scoring an average of 1.78 goals and conceding 1.48 per game. Fulham are seventh, level on ten wins but with a more modest attack (1.39 goals per game) and identical goals conceded. Both teams’ league positions are a fair reflection of their competitive output so far.

Delving deeper into the head-to-head record, United have been the dominant side at Old Trafford. Over their last seven home matches against Fulham, they have won four. However, the 1-1 draw in their prior encounter, with United only managing three shots on target, suggests Fulham are fully capable of frustrating the home side.

Manchester United come into the match with some enforced defensive changes. Matthijs de Ligt is sidelined with back problems, ruling him out for the game. For Fulham, Rodrigo Muniz, Saša Lukić, Kevin and Issa Diop are unavailable due to various injuries. The visitors must also adjust both their defense and midfield configuration in the absence of these regulars.

Taking into account the most recent consistent starters and respecting unavailable players, the probable lineups and formation (4-2-3-1) are as follows:

Manchester United (4-2-3-1)

Goalkeeper: Senne Lammens

Defenders: Diogo Dalot, Harry Maguire, Lisandro Martínez, Luke Shaw

Midfielders: Casemiro, Patrick Dorgu, Bruno Fernandes, Amad Diallo, Kobbie Mainoo

Attackers: Bryan Mbeumo

Fulham (4-2-3-1)

Goalkeeper: Bernd Leno

Defenders: Joachim Andersen, Jorge Cuenca, Timothy Castagne, Antonee Robinson

Midfielders: Sander Berge, Harrison Reed, Alex Iwobi, Harry Wilson, Emile Smith Rowe

Attackers: Raúl Jiménez

Both managers are expected to prioritize midfield control and defensive stability. Manchester United’s edge in home form and Fulham’s resilience away point to a tightly contested match with limited scoring opportunities.

The algorithm projects a match featuring under 2.5 total goals, with Manchester United favored to secure all three points—holding a 44% win probability. A 2-0 result in favor of the hosts emerges as the most likely scoreline, but given Fulham’s disciplined defensive record, margin for error is small.

Whether United can break down Fulham’s setup or if the visitors can spring a surprise remains linked to midfield battles and clinical finishing. United currently possess strong momentum at home, while Fulham’s solid unbeaten trend in recent matches ensures Carrick’s side won’t enjoy an easy path to victory.

The stage is set at Estadio Santiago Bernabéu as Real Madrid look to extend their strong form against Rayo Vallecano. With both sides experiencing contrasting fortunes this season, pressure mounts as Rayo seek a turnaround and Madrid strive to keep pace near the league summit.

Real Madrid return home well aware of their recent commanding record. With three consecutive home victories, scoring at an impressive average of 4.33 goals and conceding less than one per match over that stretch, they carry clear attacking intent into this fixture.

In contrast, Rayo Vallecano face an uphill task. They have lost their last three matches and have been winless in 8 of their last 10 away league games. That recent away run includes 40% losses by 2 or more goals, highlighting defensive vulnerabilities against high-profile opposition.

Both sides last clashed on November 9, 2025 at Vallecas, where a resolute Rayo side held Madrid to a 0-0 draw. The statistics favored Real Madrid, who managed 21 total shots and five on target compared to Rayo’s 13 with two on target. Still, Rayo’s compact shape and discipline frustrated Madrid, limiting their clear chances despite 54% ball possession and 60 dangerous attacks posted.

Overall, Real Madrid boast very favorable recent records against Rayo. Across the last 13 matches in all competitions between these sides, Madrid have notched seven wins. Looking more broadly, Real have been undefeated in 90% of their last 20 league matches, cementing their status as favorites with a remarkable home run in La Liga of 25 wins in their last 30 matches.

On the other side, Rayo Vallecano continue to grapple with inconsistency within the league. Sitting 16th in the table, they have won only five of their 21 matches and carry a negative goal difference. Alarmingly for Iñigo Pérez’s side, they have been winless in 80% of their last 20 league fixtures, and three consecutive defeats coming into this clash only add to the pressure.

Real Madrid’s defensive options are stretched with Ferland Mendy, Éder Militão, Antonio Rüdiger, and Trent Alexander-Arnold all sidelined due to injuries. The absence of Rüdiger and Mendy in particular forces a reshuffle, but Madrid’s squad depth offers quality alternatives. Rayo Vallecano, notably, have the luxury of a fully fit roster for this encounter.

Based on the trends and available lineups, a 4-3-3 remains the most probable formation for both teams.

Real Madrid probable lineup:

Goalkeeper: Thibaut Courtois

Defenders: Federico Valverde, Raúl Asencio, Álvaro Carreras, Dean Huijsen

Midfielders: Jude Bellingham, Eduardo Camavinga, Aurélien Tchouaméni

Attackers: Vinicius Junior, Kylian Mbappé, Gonzalo García

Rayo Vallecano probable lineup:

Goalkeeper: Augusto Batalla

Defenders: Pep Chavarría, Florian Lejeune, Nobel Mendy, Alfonso Espino

Midfielders: Pedro Díaz, Isi Palazón, Óscar Valentín

Attackers: Jorge de Frutos, Álvaro García, Carlos Martín

Madrid’s attackers have found consistent rhythm, averaging 2.67 goals per match in their last six outings and recording three straight wins by at least two goals. Their control of possession at home (averaging 60% in recent matches) should allow them to dictate tempo.

Rayo, meanwhile, have scored just once on average per game across recent away fixtures and have conceded twice per outing. Their struggle to consistently create high-value chances may prove costly against a Madrid side relentless in pressing and transition.

Prediction models heavily favor a home victory, assigning Real Madrid a 71% probability of winning. With recent history pointing to over 2.5 goals in the match, Madrid’s attacking prowess is primed to produce a convincing result. The most likely scenario appears to be a victory for Real Madrid by 3-0, further compounding Rayo’s struggles on the road.

The numbers side with Madrid, but Rayo’s defensive performance from their last encounter provides a glimmer of hope. It remains to be seen if lightning can strike twice in the Spanish capital.

MHPArena hosts a Bundesliga clash that brings together two sides with plenty to prove. Stuttgart, sitting fourth and pushing for Champions League places, take on Freiburg, who arrive in need of a big away performance. The match promises tactical intrigue, contrasting form stretches, and the chance for both teams to make a statement in the league.

Looking at their direct duels, the last six encounters between Stuttgart and Freiburg have been level in terms of outcomes. Each side has taken three wins. This pattern reveals a rivalry that tends to produce unpredictable results, suggesting both teams know how to exploit each other’s weaknesses.

Stuttgart’s most recent home meetings with Freiburg suggest a slight edge for the hosts, who have won two of the last five meetings at this venue by at least two goals.

Stuttgart enter the match in solid shape, with three wins, two draws, and just one defeat from their last six. They are posting an average of 1.83 goals scored while conceding only 1, and their positive approach is reflected in 51.83% average possession and 14.17 shots per game during this period.

At home, their resilience is even more notable, remaining unbeaten in the last three and not losing in 12 of the past 15 matches at MHPArena.

Freiburg’s recent form also deserves recognition, picking up four wins from their last six, drawing once, and losing just one. They match Stuttgart with an identical goals scored average (1.83), but concede a bit more at 1.5. Freiburg’s average possession sits at just over 50%, but their away displays have lacked consistency, failing to win in 83% of their last six away games.

Stuttgart have put together a strong Bundesliga campaign so far, winning 11, drawing three, and losing five of their 19 matches. With 36 goals for, 26 against, and a positive goal difference of 10, they’ve kept themselves comfortably in the European race.

Freiburg, meanwhile, are seventh with 31 goals scored and 32 conceded through 19 matches. Their negative goal difference and even spread between wins, draws, and losses (seven wins, six draws, six defeats) suggest a team with potential, but one that occasionally struggles for consistency on both sides of the pitch.

Stuttgart have posted wins in 23 of their last 40 matches in all competitions and boast a league home record that’s among the best: undefeated in 12 of their previous 15 Bundesliga matches at home, winning 67% of those.

Defensively disciplined, clean sheets have featured in 40% of their last 15 at home. They’re also dangerous going forward, averaging around six shots on target per outing at MHPArena.

Freiburg have enjoyed long stretches of pride, undefeated in 28 of their last 35 games in all competitions, but the away form is hurting them. In the last six away matches in all competitions, they have not won 83% of the time and lost half of those games.

Positively, the visitors carry a three-match unbeaten run into this clash and typically keep themselves competitive, with a reasonable share of clean sheets (nine in the previous 22 away fixtures).

Stuttgart must navigate several absences, notably at the back, with Jaquez, Tomás, Zagadou, Chabot, Stiller, Jovanovic, and Vagnoman unavailable.

Stuttgart:

Goalkeeper: Alexander Nübel

Defenders: Ramon Hendriks, Ameen Al-Dakhil, Maximilian Mittelstädt, Finn Jeltsch

Midfielders: Atakan Karazor, Jamie Leweling, Chris Führich, Badredine Bouanani

Attackers: Ermedin Demirovic, Deniz Undav

With so many usual starters out, expect Stuttgart to slightly adjust their structure, possibly utilizing a 4-2-3-1 or 4-2-2-2 variant that makes best use of squad depth.

Freiburg:

Goalkeeper: Noah Atubolu

Defenders: Lukas Kübler, Matthias Ginter, Bruno Ogbus, Philipp Treu

Midfielders: Maximilian Eggestein, Patrick Osterhage, Yuito Suzuki, Vincenzo Grifo

Attackers: Lucas Höler, Igor Matanovic

Lienhart, Irié, and Kyereh are absent for Freiburg, but most of the core starting group is available. Grifo’s recent involvement suggests a likely return to the starting 11.

Stuttgart’s imperious home record gives them the edge, especially as Freiburg’s troubling away run continues (winless in five of their last six away matches in Bundesliga action). The Forebet algorithm also points toward the hosts and assigns a 40% probability for a Stuttgart victory, projecting a 3-1 final score.

With Stuttgart keen to solidify their top-four place and Freiburg searching for a spark on the road, the edge sits firmly with Sebastian Hoeneß’s side to grab the points.

Tension is set to build in Turin as Torino, searching for a spark at home, prepare to take on Lecce. Neither side arrives with momentum, but with key battles shaping up across the pitch and both teams desperate to get back to winning ways, every pass and tackle will matter.

Recent encounters between Torino and Lecce at the Stadio Olimpico Grande Torino paint a picture of home comfort for the Granata. In the last five meetings on this ground, Torino have come out on top three times, with Lecce taking a single win while one fixture ended in a draw. That track record stands as a glimmer of hope for Torino, who are in dire need of a result to reinvigorate their campaign.

Torino's recent form, however, tells a cautionary tale. Over their last six matches, Marco Baroni's side have managed just two victories and suffered four losses. Their home stretch has been particularly rough, with three straight defeats at the Stadio Olimpico. During those home games, Torino have only found the net 0.67 times per match on average, while conceding twice each outing. Despite managing more shots on goal in these matches, finishing has abandoned them at crucial moments.

Looking at their last twelve matches across all competitions, Torino have lost eight. Ball possession has hovered below 45%, and their last seven home matches have resulted in six without a win. The clean sheet percentage has dropped to 43% over their last 40 league home shows, and half of the last sixteen Serie A home games have ended in defeat. These numbers underline a side in need of sharper defending and more consistent attacking contributions.

Lecce's picture is even more concerning. Sitting 17th in the table, Eusebio Di Francesco's men have lost four of their last six matches, failing to claim a single win. Goals have been a rare commodity, with just two scored in their last six, and only 0.33 per game on average in their last three away contests. Possession figures are among the lowest in the league, averaging just 37% over recent outings.

The main away trend for Lecce is the persistent struggle to pick up points on their travels. They have been winless in 19 of their last 23 away fixtures in all competitions and have failed to win in 16 of their last 20 league games away from home. Additionally, four of their last ten away matches have ended in defeat by a margin of two or more goals. Against a Torino side eager to stabilize, Lecce’s lack of attacking threat stands out.

Tactical approach will matter, and both managers have stuck to familiar systems in recent outings. Torino have leaned on a 3-5-2 and 3-1-4-2 formations, favoring wingbacks and numbers in midfield. Lecce largely choose a 4-2-3-1 or 4-3-3 structure, aiming for compactness and perhaps a quick transition forward.

With several important names missing, Torino will be without Zanos Savva, Gvidas Gineitis, Adam Masina, Cristiano Biraghi, Ardian Ismajli, Zakaria Aboukhlal, and Ali Dembélé due to varying injuries, which will affect both defensive solidity and depth in midfield. Lecce’s absentee list is shorter, with only Francesco Camarda unavailable.

Taking the above into account, here’s how both teams are likely to line up for this clash:

Torino

Goalkeeper: Alberto Paleari

Defenders: Saúl Coco, Guillermo Maripán, Adrien Tamèze

Midfielders: Marcus Pedersen, Nikola Vlašić, Emirhan İlkhan, Valentino Lazaro, Cesare Casadei

Attackers: Ché Adams, Cyril Ngonge

Lecce

Goalkeeper: Wladimiro Falcone

Defenders: Jamil Siebert, Antonino Gallo, Tiago Gabriel, Danilo Veiga

Midfielders: Lassana Coulibaly, Omri Gandelman, Ylber Ramadani, Riccardo Sottil, Santiago Pierotti

Attackers: Nikola Stulic

With both teams struggling to find the net and the Forebet algorithm favoring a low-scoring affair, under 2.5 goals seems likely. Torino’s historical edge at home, paired with Lecce’s extended winless run away, gives the hosts the slight advantage. The most probable outcome is a narrow 1-0 win for Torino, who are given a 42% probability of taking all three points.

If form holds, this fixture may simply come down to which side can shake their hesitancy in front of goal first.

Lyon and Lille face off at Groupama Stadium in a matchup that brings together a side in peak form against one desperate to end a worrying spiral. As Lyon ride an impressive winning streak, Lille are searching for answers after a string of difficult results.

Lyon have enjoyed remarkable success against Lille in their last six encounters, winning five and drawing one. This dominance has set a clear tone for their head-to-head battles, with Lille unable to take all three points from Lyon since well over a year ago.

When these two sides meet, Lyon seem to find another gear, with their recent form against Lille laying a psychological advantage ahead of this fixture.

Lyon’s form recently has been nothing short of exceptional. Over their last six matches in all competitions, they have notched up six consecutive wins, scoring 2.67 goals per match while conceding under one goal on average (0.83).

At home, Lyon have been clinical as well, winning all of their last three matches and conceding only an average of 0.33 goals. Their attacking unit continues to impress with an average of 3.33 shots on target and over 12 shots per match at Groupama Stadium.

Lille, on the other hand, have struggled to find consistency and results. Their previous six matches have brought just one win and five losses, with an average of 0.67 goals scored and 2.17 conceded per game. In away fixtures, Lille’s defense has been particularly porous this season and their attack has yet to truly fire.

Lyon currently sit 4th in the Ligue 1 standings, boasting 11 wins, three draws, and five losses in 19 matches. Their total of 32 goals for and only 20 against highlights a well-balanced side with a positive goal difference of 12.

Lille hold fifth in the table but trail Lyon not only in points but in overall momentum. With 10 wins, two draws, and seven losses from 19, they have scored slightly more (34) but their defense has let in 29 – nearly 1.5 goals per game.

Lyon have been a model of consistency at home. They have not lost in 10 of their last 12 home matches in all competitions, winning 80% of their last 15 at Groupama Stadium. Their recent run in Ligue 1 is equally impressive, with nine matches unbeaten out of the last 11.

Moreover, Lyon have kept a clean sheet in six of their last 15 home league matches and have won by two or more goals in 43% of their last seven Ligue 1 games. Across all competitions, they have been undefeated in 83% of their past 18 and have won by at least two goals in 38% of their past 13 fixtures.

Lille’s recent record tells a different story: winless in five of their last six, with three of those defeats coming by at least two goals. Away from home, they remain inconsistent, having lost eight out of their last fifteen on the road and winning just three in six.

Lyon

Goalkeeper: Dominik Greif

Defenders: Achraf Laâziri, Ruben Kluivert, Clinton Mata, Ainsley Maitland-Niles

Midfielders: Tyler Morton, Abner, Khalis Merah

Attackers: Pavel Sulc, Endrick, Afonso Moreira

Lille

Goalkeeper: Berke Özer

Defenders: Nathan Ngoy, Alexsandro, Thomas Meunier, Calvin Verdonk

Midfielders: Nabil Bentaleb, Ngal'ayel Mukau, Marius Broholm

Attackers: Hákon Arnar Haraldsson, Olivier Giroud, Romain Perraud

Lyon appear set to continue their strong form, especially given their recent performances both in the league and against Lille specifically. The expected starting lineup for manager Pierre Sage includes their most consistent contributors, further strengthening their prospects at home.

Lille, meanwhile, have struggled defensively and found goals hard to come by on the road. Despite possessing experienced players like Olivier Giroud and Nabil Bentaleb, Lille’s collective struggles cannot be ignored given the trends across the past several months.

Algorithm forecasts suggest a high-scoring affair, with over 2.5 goals likely and a 3-1 scoreline most probable in Lyon’s favor. With a 44% probability for a Lyon victory, the hosts have every reason to be confident ahead of this fixture.

Gil Vicente and FC Famalicão prepare to meet once more, just months after their last duel ended scoreless. Both sides are chasing positions near the top half of Liga Portugal and come into this clash almost neck and neck in the league standings.

The last showdown between these two teams, played on August 24, 2025, finished in a goalless draw. Despite the scoreline, Gil Vicente carried a noticeable attacking threat, registering 20 total shots and getting 8 on target. FC Famalicão, although more reserved, managed 11 shots with 3 on target.

Gil Vicente controlled more of the ball with 55% possession and outperformed Famalicão in dangerous attacks, tallying 46 to Famalicão's 34, which underscored their sharper offensive intent. The inability to convert chances was a key takeaway for both teams, hinting that efficiency in the final third could decide this meeting.

Both Gil Vicente and FC Famalicão show little that separates them after 19 league matches. Gil Vicente currently sit 5th with 8 wins, 7 draws, and 4 losses, boasting a goal difference of +8 with 24 scored and 16 conceded. Their tally works out to 1.26 goals for and 0.84 conceded per game.

Famalicão, just two spots lower in 7th, have matched Gil Vicente for wins (8), while drawing 5 and losing 6, aided by a slightly better defensive record. They share the same 24 goals for but have allowed just 14 against, riding a +10 goal differential. Average goals for both teams per game are identical at 1.26 but Famalicão have conceded slightly less.

Gil Vicente have shown resilience in their recent outings. Over their last 6 matches, they've lost only once, drawn 4, and won 1, scoring 1.33 but conceding 1.67 per game. At home, they're unbeaten in their last 3, picking up a win and two draws, while improving to 1.67 goals scored per match, and tightening their defence to 1.33 conceded.

Famalicão, over their previous 6, have seen a mixed run of form—winning 2, losing 4, and drawing none. They've averaged 1.17 goals per game and let in 1.5. On the road, offensive output has dropped with just 0.33 goals scored per match in their last 3, though their defence remains solid at just 0.67 against in those fixtures.

Gil Vicente's matches tend to be close, with 50% of their last 12 ending in draws. They also have remained undefeated in 82% of their last 11 in all competitions. However, a winless run in 8 of their last 10 matches in all competitions hints at difficulties in putting games away.

The home side also find comfort in Barcelos, undefeated in 9 of their last 11 home matches. But a notable downside is losing by 2 or more goals in 4 of their last 8 home matches against Famalicão, suggesting periodic vulnerabilities.

Famalicão have taken 50% of their last 14 matches in all competitions, while struggling with a high loss rate—50% across their last 12. Away from home, however, they've kept clean sheets in 42% of their last 12, and have taken exactly half of their most recent away matches, displaying a solid balance of resilience and ambition when travelling.

Gil Vicente

Goalkeeper: Andrew da Silva Ventura

Defenders: José Carlos Teixeira Lopes dos Reis Gonçalves, Marvin Adolphe Fabrice Elimbi Gilbert, Hevertton Ciriaco Santos, Antonio Espigares Morillas

Midfielders: Facundo Agustín Cáseres, Tidjany Chabrol Touré, Luís André Leite Esteves, Murilo de Souza Costa, Santiago García González

Attackers: Gustavo Miguel Pereira de Sousa Varela

With Zé Carlos sidelined through an arm injury (out for 36 matches already), Gil Vicente will lean on recent starters for the back four, including Hevertton Santos and Antonio Espigares Morillas. Andrew da Silva Ventura is likely to start in goal given his place in the last match, with Gustavo Varela expected up front in a fluid 4-2-3-1 setup.

FC Famalicão

Goalkeeper: Lazar Carević

Defenders: Rodrigo Pinheiro, Justin de Haas, Rafa Soares, Léo Realpe

Midfielders: Tom van de Looi, Sorriso, Mathias de Amorim, Gustavo Sá, Gil Dias

Attackers: Simon Elisor

Famalicão have essentially a full squad to choose from and should stick with a core that has rotated only slightly over recent matches. Carević remains a steady presence in goal, joined by a stable defensive quartet. Simon Elisor is most probable to lead the line.

Considering both sides' tendencies toward draws in their prior meetings and comparable records in the league, a closely fought match is very much in the cards. Gil Vicente's unbeaten run at home gives them a slight edge, but Famalicão's knack for away clean sheets and efficiency cannot be ignored. The probability favors a draw at 35%, with a 1-1 scoreline forecasted as the most plausible result.

Pressure is mounting in the Eredivisie as Ajax visit Excelsior at Stadion Woudestein, with both sides eager to make their mark. The two clubs arrive in contrasting form, and a closer look at their recent performances and historical encounters sets the stage for a compelling clash.

When Excelsior and Ajax go head-to-head, the scales have tipped decidedly in favor of the Amsterdam club over the years. In their last ten meetings, Ajax have emerged victorious six times, while Excelsior have claimed just one win, drawing three. This historical pattern underscores Ajax’s dominance, though Excelsior have occasionally managed to frustrate their visitors, securing draws at home in years past.

Excelsior’s recent league form is a tale of mixed results. Over their last six matches, Ruben den Uil’s side have won just once, drawn three, and lost two. They’re currently winless in their last five league matches. Defensive solidity has been a challenge, conceding an average of 1.83 goals per match during this run, while only scoring one per game. The trend remains similar at home, where they’ve picked up one win, one draw, and one loss in the last three, netting an average of just 1.33 goals and conceding 1.67.

The deeper home trend paints a broader picture for Excelsior. Across their last 22 matches in all competitions, 50% have ended in defeat, and they’ve managed just nine wins in the last 15 home outings. Their ability to keep a clean sheet at Stadion Woudestein is respectable, with 43% of their last 30 home games ending without conceding. However, facing Ajax has posed major problems: Excelsior have lost 67% of their last six home fixtures against the Amsterdam side and been beaten by a margin of two or more goals in seven of the last 13 overall encounters.

Ajax, under Fred Grim, continue to impress with consistency. Sitting third in the standings after 20 games, they have recorded 10 wins, seven draws, and just three losses, scoring 39 goals and conceding 26. Ajax average 1.95 goals per match, nearly double Excelsior’s attacking output. Their last six Eredivisie fixtures have produced three wins, two draws, and a single defeat, with an attacking return of 1.83 goals per game and conceding 2.17.

The away form of Ajax has been particularly noteworthy. Over the past 12 matches in all competitions, they’ve gone unbeaten in ten, and on the road, they are unbeaten in six out of seven. Ajax have also managed to win by two or more goals in three of their last seven away matches. As for streaks, the visitors are now undefeated in their last three games in all competitions.

Ajax’s league form remains robust with just three losses in their last 20 Eredivisie fixtures, having gone undefeated in 17 of those matches. Their ability to secure big victories is highlighted by eight wins by a two-goal margin or more in their last 21 league games. Defensively, Ajax aren't the tightest at the back, but their offensive firepower has often compensated, especially in away matches.

The lineup news is significant. Excelsior have no sidelined players confirmed, which gives Ruben den Uil options to stick with familiar faces and systems. Ajax, on the other hand, are without Steven Berghuis due to a groin injury, sidelined for 20 matches, but have otherwise shown depth and rotation to cover for absences.

Excelsior Probable Lineup
Goalkeeper: Stijn van Gassel
Defenders: Ilias Bronkhorst, Rick Meissen, Casper Widell, Arthur Zagré
Midfielders: Lennard Hartjes, Emil Hansson, Irakli Yegoian, Noah Naujoks, Derensili Sanches Fernandes
Attackers: Jerolldino Bergraaf

Ajax Probable Lineup
Goalkeeper: Vitezslav Jaros
Defenders: Lucas Rosa, Anton Gaaei, Ko Itakura, Youri Baas
Midfielders: Youri Regeer, Davy Klaassen, Sean Steur
Attackers: Kasper Dolberg, Mika Godts, Rayane Bounida

The probable formation for Excelsior leans towards a 4-2-3-1, favoring control and midfield balance based on their most used lineups. Ajax are likely to persist with their familiar 4-3-3, offering the balance between a dynamic attack and a stable midfield core.

The statistical indicators and trends point towards Ajax holding the upper hand. They are undefeated in ten of their last twelve, and their attacking prowess coupled with historical advantage over Excelsior suggests they should be able to take all three points. The probability stands at 56% for an Ajax victory, with a predicted scoreline of 3-1 given their strong offensive numbers and Excelsior’s recent defensive frailties.

All evidence from current form, statistical trends, and probable lineups suggests Ajax are well poised to continue their strong run. Excelsior will need to produce a resolute defensive performance and take their chances if they are to disrupt the visitors’ momentum.
